title: Were Veda Sanskrit and old Avestan mutually intelligible? - Quora

response.answer_text: Those two languages being quite close to each other, there could have been a fair degree of mutual intelligibility (though not 100%) between the two. But there were both orthographic and phonetic differences between the two even for words with the same meaning, as they were not identical but cognates. This phenomenon would have given rise to some difficulties in mutual understanding. The real “problem”, however, was more likely related to culture than purely linguistics. There are enough mythological and ancient anecdotal accounts to believe that the Vedic and the Avestan communities, though originally having the same ancestors, separated into two groups due to differences in religious belief and value system. So much so, that they not only made derogatory comments about each other but also demonised the gods of each other. Because of such quarrel brewing, no wonder that sooner or later the two groups should split geographically. Hence they had their respective homelands in ancient Persia and the Indus region. Politics must have also played a role in this. Linguistic divergence was the consequence of that split. There followed the stigmatization of the other group's language as something ignoble. That, in effect, created a linguistic barrier between the two groups and finally undermined mutual intelligibility.

Q:Were Veda Sanskrit and old Avestan mutually intelligible? Thank you for this question. I am not really an expert, but I may provide some of my observations. Sanskrit and Avestan are closely related languages with similar grammatical principles and numerous cognates, similarly like Italian and Spanish. You can find words which are basically identical, like Sanskrit/Avestan naman (name), ushtra (camel) etc. Then you have cognates which are basically the same, except that their similarity is somewhat obscured by a divergence of a certain sounds. It is comparable to Italian generale and Spanish general. Basically the same word, but the “G” is like English “J” in the first case and as “KH” in the second. Some possible divergences between Sanskrit and Avestan cognates: S ↔ H: soma ↔ haoma (a pressed plant nectar) H↔Z: ahuti ↔ azuiti (an oblation) H ↔ ZH: ahi ↔ azhi (a serpent); ZH = Ž(ʒ), like French J J ↔ Z: vajra ↔ vazra (a tough weapon) T ↔ TH: mantra ↔ manthra (an utterance) K ↔ KH: kshatra ↔ khshathra (dominion) BH ↔ B: bhratr ↔ bratar SH ↔ S: shyena ↔ saena (a raptor) SHV ↔ SP: ashva ↔ aspa (a horse) RT ↔ SH: martya ↔ mashya (a mortal; a human) The Avestan RT ↔ SH shift seems to be a less archaic characteristic. Its specific is that it happens only when R and T are next to each other, but not when a vowel is between them. You thus have amesha (immortal; amarta in Sanskrit), yet ameretat (immortality). Regarding the S ↔ H divergence, it may be sometimes also S ↔ NGH in the middle of the word: Nasatya ↔ Naonghaithya. As you can note, the Avestan also commonly contains extra diphthongs if compared to Sanskrit: Arya ↔ Airya (an Aryan), deva ↔ daeva (a supernatural being), hotr ↔ zaotar (a priestly officiator), ahuti ↔ azuiti (an oblation), Sushravas ↔ Haosravah (“of Good Fame”) etc. Outside the difference in diphthongs, there can be sometimes also a difference simply in the usage of different vowels: hiranya ↔ zaranya (gold). The Sanskrit terms starting with “R+consonant” can have Avestan equivalents where a vowel “A” is inserted at the beginning, like rshti ↔ arshti (a spear). It also means that while an extra “A” at the beginning which is not a part of the root of the word can mean a negation in both Avestan and Sanskrit, it does not in the Avestan “R+consonant” words. The Avestan negation would be anarshti (“a non-spear”, a hypothetical word which I just made up). Of course, these were examples of relatively ideal cognates which are separated by merely one particular shift, which is not always the case. Moreover, you also need to be careful about a few false friends, the same-like words with a different meaning, for example: dasyu X dahyu (savages X a country) marya X mairya (a young man X a thug) urvara X urvara (a fertile field X a plant); in Italian albero (a tree) Outside this vast amount of cognate words, you will find also words without a cognate in the other language. For example: Sanskrit: atman (self; a soul) brahman (something like “an essence”) agni (a fire) Avestan: urvan (a soul) daena (an inspiration) atar (a fire) Of course, there would be also some more complications, like accent differences.
